policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing access controls including privileged function restrictions
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.07 requires preventing non-privileged users from executing privileged functions, necessitating policy-level governance

policies.name: Privileged Access Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining privileged functions, authorized users, and logging requirements for privileged activities
policies.rationale: NIST discussion defines privileged functions as establishing system accounts, performing system integrity checks, conducting patching operations, changing system configuration settings, or administering cryptographic key management activities

procedures.name: Privileged Function Access Control Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for identifying privileged functions, restricting access to authorized users only, and implementing technical controls to prevent non-privileged user execution
procedures.rationale: Control requires preventing non-privileged users from executing privileged functions through specific technical implementation

procedures.name: Privileged Activity Logging Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Process for configuring systems to log all privileged function executions including what function was executed, by whom, when, and from where
procedures.rationale: NIST 03.01.07(b) explicitly requires logging the execution of privileged functions to detect misuse and mitigate risks from advanced persistent threats

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Function Execution Logs
executionEvidence.description: System audit logs showing: privileged function executed, user account, timestamp, source system/IP, success/failure status. Must capture events like account creation, configuration changes, patch installations, cryptographic key operations
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires logging privileged functions as detection mechanism for misuse from insider threats and APTs; daily review aligns with CIS Critical Security Control 6.2

executionEvidence.name: System Configuration Documentation - Privilege Restrictions
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: which privileged functions exist in the environment, technical controls preventing non-privileged access (UAC, sudo, RBAC configurations), list of authorized privileged users per function
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of 03.01.07(a) requirement to prevent non-privileged execution; quarterly review ensures configuration remains accurate

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Account Activity Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: review of privileged function execution logs, anomalies identified, investigation outcomes, corrective actions taken, reviewer signatures, review date
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates that logging is actively monitored to detect misuse as intended by NIST; monthly frequency aligns with NIST SP 800-53 AU-6 recommendations

operationalActivities: Configure systems to prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions through UAC, sudo, or RBAC
Enable comprehensive logging of all privileged function executions
Review privileged function execution logs daily for anomalies
Conduct monthly analysis of privileged activity patterns
Quarterly review of privileged function access lists and technical restrictions
Investigate any unauthorized privileged function execution attempts immediately

policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing authentication and access controls including account lockout provisions
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.08 requires enforcing limits on invalid logon attempts, necessitating policy-level guidance on acceptable thresholds

policies.name: Account Lockout Policy
policies.description: Policy defining the number of consecutive invalid logon attempts allowed, lockout duration, lockout release procedures, and specific requirements for different system types
policies.rationale: NIST requires organization-defined number of attempts during organization-defined time period, with automatic lockout or other actions when exceeded

procedures.name: Account Lockout Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for configuring account lockout settings on systems including: lockout threshold (e.g., 5 attempts), observation window (e.g., 15 minutes), lockout duration (e.g., 30 minutes), exceptions for service accounts
procedures.rationale: Control requires implementing automatic lockout mechanisms at system and application levels as specified in NIST discussion

procedures.name: Account Unlock Procedure
procedures.description: Process for authorized personnel to manually unlock accounts including: verification of user identity, documentation requirements, notification procedures, investigation of repeated lockouts
procedures.rationale: NIST 03.01.08(b) allows lockout until released by administrator as one of the acceptable responses

executionEvidence.name: System Configuration Screenshots - Account Lockout Settings
executionEvidence.description: Screenshots or configuration exports showing: lockout threshold (number of attempts), observation window (time period), lockout duration or auto-release setting, systems/applications covered, configuration date
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of 03.01.08(a) requirement to enforce attempt limits; quarterly verification ensures settings remain configured per policy

executionEvidence.name: Account Lockout Event Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: locked accounts during reporting period, usernames, lockout timestamps, number of failed attempts, unlock method (automatic vs manual), unlock timestamp, IP addresses of failed attempts
executionEvidence.rationale: Provides evidence that lockout mechanisms are functioning; monthly reporting allows identification of brute force attack patterns or user training needs

executionEvidence.name: Account Unlock Request Tickets
executionEvidence.description: Helpdesk tickets showing: unlock requests, user identity verification performed, administrator who unlocked, timestamp, investigation notes for repeated lockouts, user notification
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates 03.01.08(b) administrator-release mechanism is properly executed with appropriate controls

executionEvidence.name: Failed Authentication Log Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: review of failed logon attempts, patterns identified, potential brute force attacks detected, IP blocks implemented, review date, analyst signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states monitoring unsuccessful attempts allows organizations to detect attacks; weekly review provides timely detection

operationalActivities: Configure account lockout thresholds on all systems (typically 5-10 invalid attempts)
Set lockout observation windows (typically 15-30 minutes)
Configure automatic lockout release (typically 30-60 minutes) or require administrator unlock
Monitor account lockout events weekly for attack patterns
Process account unlock requests with identity verification
Investigate accounts with repeated lockouts for compromised credentials
Quarterly verification that lockout settings remain properly configured

policies.name: Acceptable Use Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy defining acceptable and unacceptable use of information systems, user responsibilities, monitoring provisions, and consequences of violations
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.09 requires displaying system use notifications before access; the content of these notifications derives from the acceptable use policy

policies.name: System Access Policy
policies.description: Policy requiring system use notifications to be displayed before granting access, specifying required content elements (privacy notices, security notices, monitoring notices, consent provisions)
policies.rationale: NIST requires system use notification message with privacy and security notices consistent with applicable CUI rules

procedures.name: System Use Notification Implementation Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for implementing system use banners including: approved banner text (legal review), technical configuration on different system types (Windows, Linux, network devices), banner placement before authentication, verification testing
procedures.rationale: Control requires displaying notifications before granting access across multiple system types; NIST discussion states messages displayed before individuals log in

procedures.name: Banner Content Review and Approval Procedure
procedures.description: Process for reviewing and approving banner content including: legal review for CUI compliance, privacy notice requirements, security notice elements, annual review schedule, approval authorities
procedures.rationale: NIST requires content be consistent with applicable CUI rules, necessitating formal review process

executionEvidence.name: System Use Notification Banner Screenshots
executionEvidence.description: Screenshots showing: banner text displayed before login on representative systems (Windows workstations, servers, VPN portal, web applications), banner content including privacy and security notices, timestamp of screenshot, system identifier
executionEvidence.rationale: Provides visual evidence that banners are displayed as required; quarterly verification ensures banners remain active and unmodified

executionEvidence.name: Banner Configuration Files
executionEvidence.description: Configuration files or exports showing: banner text configured in systems (Group Policy, SSH banner, web server configs), systems covered, configuration date, change history
executionEvidence.frequency: Annual review with updates as needed
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates technical implementation of banner display; annual review ensures configurations remain current

executionEvidence.name: System Inventory with Banner Status
executionEvidence.description: Inventory showing: all systems processing CUI, banner implementation status (yes/no), banner type (automated message, poster for air-gapped systems), verification date, exceptions documented
executionEvidence.rationale: Ensures comprehensive coverage; NIST discussion notes human interfaces require banners, non-human interfaces do not; quarterly review identifies new systems needing banners

executionEvidence.name: Banner Content Legal Review Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: current approved banner text, legal review date, reviewer name/signature, approval for CUI compliance, next review due date
executionEvidence.frequency: Annual or when CUI rules change
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates content is consistent with applicable CUI rules as required by NIST

operationalActivities: Configure system use notification banners on all systems before login screens
Ensure banner content includes privacy notices, security notices, and monitoring statements
Quarterly verification that banners are displayed on all applicable systems
Annual legal review of banner content for CUI rule compliance
Update banner configurations when CUI requirements change
Document exceptions for systems without human interfaces
For air-gapped systems, post physical banners/posters if automated banners not feasible

policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing access controls including device lock requirements for unattended systems
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.10 requires preventing access via device locks, necessitating policy-level guidance on lock triggers and behaviors

policies.name: Device Security Policy
policies.description: Policy defining device lock requirements including: maximum inactivity timeout (e.g., 15 minutes), user-initiated lock requirements, re-authentication requirements, screen concealment provisions, device types covered
policies.rationale: NIST requires organization-defined time period of inactivity and specifications for device lock behavior

procedures.name: Device Lock Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for configuring device lock settings including: inactivity timeout values for different device types, screen saver/lock screen settings, re-authentication requirements, publicly viewable image selection (no CUI display), configuration methods (Group Policy, MDM)
procedures.rationale: Control requires specific technical implementation of automatic and user-initiated locks; NIST discussion notes locks can be at OS or application level

procedures.name: Device Lock User Training Procedure
procedures.description: Process for training users on device lock requirements including: when to manually lock devices (leaving workstation), how to initiate locks (keyboard shortcuts), understanding of automatic lock behavior, prohibition of circumvention
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states user-initiated device locking requires users to take physical action to initiate the lock, necessitating user training

executionEvidence.name: Device Lock Configuration Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Configuration exports or screenshots showing: inactivity timeout settings (e.g., 15 minutes), lock on resume from sleep enabled, require password on wake enabled, screen saver settings, device types covered (workstations, laptops, mobile devices), configuration date
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of 03.01.10(a) automatic lock trigger; quarterly verification ensures settings remain configured per policy

executionEvidence.name: Lock Screen Configuration Screenshots
executionEvidence.description: Screenshots showing: lock screen appearance (background image), no CUI visible on lock screen, authentication required to unlock, user name displayed or concealed as per policy
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates 03.01.10(c) requirement to conceal information with publicly viewable image; ensures CUI is not visible while locked

executionEvidence.name: Device Lock Compliance Scan Reports
executionEvidence.description: Automated scan reports showing: devices scanned, lock screen timeout values detected, non-compliant devices (timeout too long or disabled), remediation actions, scan date, percentage compliance
executionEvidence.rationale: Provides ongoing verification that device lock settings remain properly configured across device fleet; monthly scans detect configuration drift

executionEvidence.name: User Training Records - Device Lock
executionEvidence.description: Training records showing: employees trained on device lock requirements, training completion date, topics covered (manual lock procedures, automatic lock behavior, policy requirements), quiz/acknowledgment
executionEvidence.frequency: Annual training, within 30 days for new hires
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion notes user-initiated locking is behavior-based, requiring user awareness and compliance; annual training reinforces requirements

operationalActivities: Configure automatic device lock after maximum 15 minutes of inactivity
Enable device lock on sleep/screen saver activation
Configure lock screens to display publicly viewable images with no CUI
Require authentication (password, PIN, biometric) to unlock devices
Train users on manual device lock procedures and requirements
Monthly compliance scans to verify lock configurations across all devices
Remediate non-compliant devices identified in scans
Quarterly verification that configurations remain properly set

policies.name: Access Control Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing access controls including session management and automatic termination requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.11 requires automatic termination of user sessions under defined conditions, necessitating policy-level governance

policies.name: Session Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining session termination trigger conditions including: idle timeout values (e.g., 30 minutes), time-of-day restrictions if applicable, incident-triggered termination criteria, different timeout values for different privilege levels or risk levels
policies.rationale: NIST requires organization-defined conditions or trigger events for session termination; NIST discussion lists examples including inactivity periods, time-of-day restrictions, targeted incident responses

procedures.name: Session Timeout Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for configuring session timeout settings including: idle timeout values for different systems (workstations, servers, web applications, VPN), trigger events beyond inactivity, configuration methods, testing procedures
procedures.rationale: Control requires automatic session termination; NIST discussion distinguishes logical sessions from network connections, requiring specific technical implementation

procedures.name: Session Termination Monitoring Procedure
procedures.description: Process for monitoring session termination events including: log review for terminated sessions, validation that termination triggers are working, investigation of sessions not terminated as expected
procedures.rationale: Ongoing monitoring needed to ensure automatic termination mechanisms function correctly

executionEvidence.name: Session Timeout Configuration Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Configuration exports showing: idle timeout values set (e.g., 30 minutes for standard users, 15 minutes for privileged sessions), systems/applications covered, time-of-day restrictions if applicable, configuration date, configuration method (Group Policy, application settings)
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of automatic session termination requirements; quarterly verification ensures configurations remain set per policy

executionEvidence.name: Session Termination Event Logs
executionEvidence.description: System logs showing: user sessions automatically terminated, termination trigger (inactivity timeout, time-of-day, incident response), username, session duration, termination timestamp
executionEvidence.frequency: Continuous logging with weekly sampling review
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates that automatic session termination is functioning; weekly sampling confirms mechanisms are working as intended

executionEvidence.name: Session Management Compliance Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: systems reviewed for session timeout configuration, configuration compliance status, non-compliant systems identified, remediation actions, review date, percentage compliance
executionEvidence.rationale: Provides ongoing verification that session termination settings remain properly configured; monthly reviews detect configuration drift

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Session Timeout Verification
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: privileged/administrative sessions have shorter timeout values than standard users, timeout values configured (e.g., 10-15 minutes), verification date, exceptions documented with risk acceptance
executionEvidence.rationale: Privileged sessions pose higher risk and typically require more aggressive timeout values; CIS benchmarks recommend shorter timeouts for elevated privileges

operationalActivities: Configure automatic session termination after 30 minutes of inactivity (standard users)
Configure automatic session termination after 15 minutes of inactivity (privileged users)
Implement time-of-day restrictions if required by organizational policy
Enable session termination logging on all systems
Weekly sampling review of session termination logs to verify functionality
Monthly compliance scans to verify timeout configurations across all systems
Quarterly review and validation of timeout values remain appropriate
Enable forced session termination capability for incident response scenarios

policies.name: Remote Access Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing remote access including: allowed remote access types (VPN, RDP, cloud services), usage restrictions, configuration requirements, connection requirements, authorization processes, monitoring provisions, privileged remote access restrictions
policies.rationale: NIST 03.01.12(a) requires establishing usage restrictions, configuration requirements, and connection requirements for each type of allowable remote access

policies.name: Acceptable Use Policy
policies.description: Policy defining acceptable use of remote access including: approved use cases, prohibited activities while connected remotely, device security requirements, user responsibilities
policies.rationale: Remote access represents significant vulnerability per NIST discussion; acceptable use policy defines boundaries for remote workers

procedures.name: Remote Access Authorization Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for authorizing remote access including: request submission, business justification, manager approval, IT security review, access type determination, duration (temporary vs permanent), documentation requirements
procedures.rationale: NIST 03.01.12(b) explicitly requires authorizing each type of remote access prior to establishing connections

procedures.name: Remote Access Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Process for configuring remote access including: VPN client deployment, endpoint security requirements (antivirus, patching, firewall), multi-factor authentication setup, managed access control point configuration, split-tunnel prohibition
procedures.rationale: NIST 03.01.12(c) requires routing remote access through authorized and managed access control points; specific configuration needed

procedures.name: Privileged Remote Access Procedure
procedures.description: Process for authorizing and monitoring privileged remote access including: additional approval requirements, jump host/PAM solution usage, session recording requirements, restricted command execution, time limitations
procedures.rationale: NIST 03.01.12(d) requires authorizing remote execution of privileged commands and remote access to security-relevant information; NIST discussion emphasizes restricting privileged remote access reduces exposure

executionEvidence.name: Remote Access Authorization Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: user requesting access, remote access type requested (VPN, RDP, cloud service), business justification, manager approval date and signature, IT security review date, access granted date, access expiration date if temporary
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates 03.01.12(b) requirement that each type of remote access is authorized prior to connection

executionEvidence.name: Remote Access Connection Logs
executionEvidence.description: Logs showing: user connecting remotely, source IP address, connection timestamp, disconnect timestamp, session duration, remote access type used, endpoint security posture at connection, MFA status
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states monitoring remote access methods allows organizations to detect attacks; daily review enables timely detection of anomalies

executionEvidence.name: Remote Access Infrastructure Configuration
executionEvidence.description: Documentation showing: VPN concentrators configured as managed access control points, network diagram showing remote access routing, split-tunneling disabled, MFA enforced, endpoint security checks enabled, configuration date, change history
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates 03.01.12(c) requirement to route remote access through managed access control points; quarterly review ensures configurations remain secure

executionEvidence.name: Privileged Remote Access Session Logs
executionEvidence.description: Logs showing: privileged remote access sessions, user identity, privileged commands executed remotely, access to security-relevant information, session recording file references, approval documentation, timestamp
executionEvidence.rationale: Addresses 03.01.12(d) authorization requirement for remote privileged commands; NIST discussion emphasizes restricting these activities reduces organizational exposure

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly Remote Access User Review
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: all users with remote access, access types authorized per user, last connection date, inactive remote access (no use in 90 days), unauthorized access removed, review date, reviewer signature
executionEvidence.rationale: Ensures remote access remains limited to those with current business need; CIS Critical Security Control 6.3 recommends regular access reviews

executionEvidence.name: Remote Access Security Monitoring Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: unusual remote access patterns detected, geographic anomalies (logins from unexpected countries), brute force attempts, successful connections from known malicious IPs, investigation outcomes, remediation actions
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes remote access is significant potential vulnerability exploited by adversaries; weekly monitoring enables timely threat detection

operationalActivities: Review and approve remote access requests before granting access
Configure VPN and other remote access solutions as managed access control points
Enforce multi-factor authentication for all remote access
Disable split-tunneling to ensure all remote traffic routes through managed access points
Monitor remote access connection logs daily for anomalies
Require additional approval for privileged remote access
Record privileged remote access sessions for audit
Conduct weekly security monitoring of remote access patterns
Quarterly review of all remote access authorizations to remove unused access
Quarterly verification of remote access infrastructure configurations
Immediately revoke remote access upon employee termination or role change
